Are you actually using Elasticsearch?

From their docs:
> However, because GET with a request body is not universally supported, the search API also accepts POST requests:

This is the first I've heard of GET requests supporting a body, and it sounds very non-standard. Some quick searching [reveals](https://stackoverflow.com/a/983458) that others (including the creator of the REST architecture) feel similarly about this.

Is there any reason you can't change this to be a POST?

Legacy integration for starters.
We also have layer 4 WAF supporting this feature.
Further reading with reveal that the direction loosens (removes) comments
about get body's.

Get is generally deemed by infra and ACL to be non mutating and a get body
is a long standing way to overcome long Param restrictions.

JVM libs being used do not have this limitation.

This is interesting. While `GET` requests are not identified as payload-bearing requests by the standard, you're right that the standard doesn't directly prohibit payloads in `GET` requests. That being said, they are very unorthodox, and `GET` handlers with payloads are likely to be a mistake rather than intended.

I propose that we change the hard error into a warning. This way, we can still catch mistakes while allowing payloads for `GET` requests when absolutely necessary.

[RFC 7231, section 4.3.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.1) says this about `GET`, and uses similar language for several other methods.

> A payload within a GET request message has no defined semantics;
> sending a payload body on a GET request might cause some existing
> implementations to reject the request.

In summary, current Rocket behavior, going off of `lib/src/http/method.rs`:
Body allowed: PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH
Body not allowed: GET, HEAD, CONNECT, TRACE, OPTIONS

And according to my interpretation of RFC 7231 and RFC 5789:
Body allowed: PUT, POST, PATCH
Body not allowed: HEAD, TRACE
Standard explicitly leaves undefined: GET, OPTIONS, DELETE, CONNECT

I agree that Rocket should additionally support bodies on `GET` and potentially also `OPTIONS`, since there appear to reasonable and/or preexisting uses for them. I also agree that a warning is reasonable for these "unorthodox" payload-accepting methods. I have no opinion on `CONNECT`.

Hi the point I was making is that we use get with payload.
It's not an error but a legitimate pattern but rarely seen.
We have a JSON or XML body describing the complex query.

Similarly a post request might contain query parameters.

Three difference between the two method types is semantic only and not
technical.

My recommendation is to distinguish Get from post only in terms of name.

issue.title: GET should support payloads

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

issue.body:
Currently, when trying to specify a `data` field for a GET route:

```
    #[get("/testGetBody", data="<data>", )]
    fn test_get_body(data: String) -> String {
        format!("{}-SUCCESS", data)
    }
```

This error is generated at compile time:

```
   Compiling http-api-server v0.1.0 (file:///home/micucci/src/git/paidyx/http-api-server-rust)
error: `data` route parameters can only be used with payload supporting methods
   --> src/lib.rs:371:27
    |
371 |     #[get("/testGetBody", data="<data>")]
    |                           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    |
    = note: 'GET' does not support payloads
```

However, according to the HTTP Spec section 4.3:

```
 The presence of a message-body in a request is signaled by the
   inclusion of a Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field in
   the request's message-headers. A message-body MUST NOT be included in
   a request if the specification of the request method (section 5.1.1)
   does not allow sending an entity-body in requests. 
```

Section 9.3 (GET) has no verbiage forbidding a message-body entity (other sections, like TRACE, specifically forbid it).

This is discussed here:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2064281/sending-post-data-with-get-request-valid

For an example, the ElasticSearch API allows a GET with an entity body.  And the spec does not preclude it.  Even though it is not common, and many people have varying opinions on whether it "should" be done, because it is allowed by the standard, I feel a framework like Rocket should allow it, and let the framework user decide whether to implement it or not.

Hi, is there a way to silent the warning when we do this on purpose?
`#[rocket::get("/", format = "application/json", data = "<data>")]`
I don't know the warning type to allow it with `#[allow(warning_type)]`

There is a //FIXME comment on the [related warning generation](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/56a617262525de758cb47a0d71049db948f24bbd/core/codegen/src/attribute/route.rs#L62), I don't know really know what it means.
I'd also like a way to silent this warning.

I'd like if the warning would return a non 0 exit code, 
```bash
warning: `data` used with non-payload-supporting method
   --> src/routes/network/root.rs:174:51
    |
174 | #[get("/instances/<instance_id>/network/routing", data = "<query>")]
```
